text: austria will become the first european
union country to reimpose a nationwide
coronavirus lockdown as it tries to slow
a record surge in infections the
austrian chancellor alexander
schullenberg told a press conference the
measure would begin on monday and last a
maximum of 20 days he also announced
austria would make it a legal
requirement to get vaccinated from
february next year well our health
correspondent naomi grimley is with me
and it was just a few days ago that
australia
austria
introduced a partial lockdown for those
who are unvaccinated this goes even
further it does indeed i think that was
partly because that was seen as
unsustainable
secondly because the case rates in
austria are such that they they really
need to get ahead of this now and they
consider the best way to do this is to
close bars and restaurants to put
schools back on online and to basically
be in a lockdown state for the next 10
days they'll review it after that
and see whether they extend it if
necessary but it's really a sign of a
country getting to grips with with rates
which have taken them by surprise in the
last couple of weeks and arguably the
most significant thing it's done is
require uh the population by law to get
vaccinated come early february and is
that is that unprecedented have any
other countries gone that far because i
know there are mandates saying the u.s
for certain sectors like health care
workers and so on has any country gone
as far as that making it mandatory for
everyone to have a vaccine not in the
western world but there are a handful of
countries that have done it globally
indonesia is one turkmenistan is another
but it's tended to be something that
national governments don't really want
to do obviously because it is the kind
of thing which would have civil
liberties campaigners worried and
possibly you know cause public unrest
you mentioned the high rates of cases in
austria of course we look across the the
water we look at what's going on on the
continent and wonder how it compares
with the situation here in the uk how
does it compare well i think we've got a
graph which shows you exactly what is
happening in austria at the moment look
at that red line it's gone into what the
scientists call exponential growth now
that's a much worse position at the
moment than the uk but the uk has had
really high rates all through the the
summer and autumn which has obviously
been quite controversial also you can
see other countries tracking austria so
the netherlands which has got good
vaccination rates better than austria
incidentally is also
on that steep curve i should just
mention that when it comes to austria's
vaccination rate 67 of the population is
fully vaccinated and that's essentially
why they're they are in this fix because
there's a significant pocket of the
population who are unvaccinated hence
this this new law which will come in in
february and the direction in terms of
the situation here in the uk um the
latest stats suggest that actually uh a
smaller proportion of the population
currently has covered but there was a
caveat with that about the direction
cases are going in day by day yeah
exactly they're different indicators
that people use the office for national
statistics goes door-to-door and swaps
uh the general population and theirs at
the moment shows that one in 65 of us
have covid that's down from last week
which was one in 60 but when it comes to
those daily rates which the government
publishes they are on an upward curve
again and the sort of worry for health
experts is that as we go into christmas
there's more mixing you know it has been
bouncing around is britain now going to
see another sort of upsurge or have they
had enough infection in the population
hitherto to mean they've got a bit more
what's called population resistance uh
you know fewer people are going to get
ill now because they've been infected
over the summer and in the early autumn
okay naomi many thanks indeed our health
